title: 104_s1483
content:
The "Victim Rights and Domestic Violence Prevention Act of 1995" includes provisions for equal protection for victims and addresses domestic violence issues. It covers rights such as an impartial jury, rebuttal of attacks on the victim's character, victim's right to speak at sentencing, fair treatment in legal proceedings, notice of offender release, and balance in rules committees. The "Victim Rights and Domestic Violence Prevention Act of 1995" includes provisions for equal protection for victims. It covers rights such as an impartial jury and rebuttal of attacks on the victim's character. SEC. 102 amends Rule 404(a)(1) of the Federal Rules of Evidence to allow evidence of the accused's character if evidence of the victim's character is presented. SEC. 103 grants victims the right to speak at sentencing. SEC. 103 amends Rule 32 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to define the right of allocution in sentencing for victims, allowing parents, legal guardians, family members, or relatives to speak on behalf of the victim if they are deceased, incapacitated, below 18 years old, or incompetent. SEC. 104. RIGHT OF THE VICTIM TO FAIR TREATMENT IN LEGAL PROCEEDINGS. Rules of Professional Conduct for Lawyers in Federal Practice are enacted as an appendix to title 28, United States Code. The Rules of Professional Conduct for Lawyers in Federal Practice include rules regarding scope, abuse of victims, duty of enquiry, duty to expedite litigation, and duty to prevent the commission of crime. These rules apply to lawyers representing clients in proceedings before Federal tribunals, which are defined as courts of the United States or Federal agencies with adjudicatory functions. Lawyers are prohibited from engaging in actions that increase litigation expenses for others or cause distress without a substantial purpose. Rule 3 of the Rules of Professional Conduct for Lawyers in Federal Practice states that lawyers must elicit a truthful account of material facts from their clients, especially in criminal or civil cases. This includes obtaining a complete account of alleged criminal activity if the client admits involvement, and relevant facts for a defense of alibi if the client denies involvement. The Rules of Professional Conduct for Lawyers in Federal Practice require lawyers to seek expeditious litigation and prevent the commission of crimes by disclosing relevant information obtained from the representation of a client. A lawyer must disclose information obtained from a client to prevent the commission of a crime or unlawful act, as required by law. This includes preventing crimes involving force, serious bodily injury, sexual assault, or child molestation. The definition of 'crime' includes offenses under US or State law. The definition of 'unlawful act' refers to an act that violates either US federal law or state law. SEC. 105. USE OF NOTICE CONCERNING RELEASE OF OFFENDER. Section 4042(b) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking paragraph (4). SEC. 106. BALANCE IN THE COMPOSITION OF RULES COMMITTEES. Section 2073 of title 28, United States Code is amended to ensure a balance in the composition of committees making recommendations on rules affecting criminal cases. Members representing defendants should not exceed those representing the Government or a State in criminal case reviews. The amendment to Section 2073 of title 28, United States Code ensures a balance in committee composition for rules affecting criminal cases, limiting the number of members representing defendants to not exceed those representing the Government or a State in criminal case reviews. TITLE II--DOMESTIC VIOLENCE

SEC. 201. DEATH PENALTY FOR FATAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE OFFENSES. Amends Sections 2261(b)(1) and 2262(b)(1) of title 18, United States Code to allow for the death penalty.

SEC. 202. EVIDENCE OF DEFENDANT'S DISPOSITION TOWARD VICTIM IN DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CASES AND OTHER CASES. Amends Rule 404(b) of the Federal Rules of Evidence to include evidence of a defendant's disposition toward a particular individual.

SEC. 203. BATTERED WOMEN'S SYNDROME EVIDENCE. SEC. 203. BATTERED WOMEN'S SYNDROME EVIDENCE. Amends Rule 702 of the Federal Rules of Evidence to allow testimony on victims' behavior and mental/emotional conditions to explain actions like failure to report offenses or cooperate in investigations. Chapter 109A of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section requiring testing for human immunodeficiency virus upon request of the victim in cases of certain offenses. Follow-up tests are also mandated at 6 and 12 months unless no risk of transmission is determined by the judicial officer. The court may order HIV testing within 24 hours of arrest, with follow-up tests at 6 and 12 months if deemed necessary. Testing can be required at any time during the legal process or after conviction. Follow-up testing can be canceled if no risk of transmission is found. Follow-up testing under this section can be canceled if a positive virus test result is obtained or if all charges are acquitted or dismissed. Test results must be disclosed to the judicial officer, court, victim, government attorney, and the person tested, with counseling provided if requested. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance sentences for offenders who knew they were infected with HIV, except if they did not engage in conduct risking transmission to the victim. Amendments are made to the Testing Provisions of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 regarding testing of defendants for HIV and disclosure of test results to the victim or their guardian. Recipients have the option to decline counseling. Amendments are made to the Testing Provisions of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 regarding testing of defendants for HIV and disclosure of test results to the victim or their guardian. The victim or the Government may obtain an order under paragraph (1) by showing that a sexual assault involves conduct posing a risk of transmission of the etiologic agent for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Amendments are made to the Testing Provisions of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, including changes to counseling requirements and the removal of a specific subparagraph.
